title: Good job volunteers.
body:
Just had a bunch of posts deleted, because how dare i talk bad to a volunteer.

Hell how dare i make a legitimate criticism that the volunteer is busy not doing his job, and is busy fighting with someone on boards instead.

Quality job guys.

You wonder why i have no respect for you guys.

replies.body:
I've stopped responding to you, because it just gets all aggressive and is frankly a headache I don't care to have, so I won't save just this once.

Regarding the comment you reference in particular. This isn't a job. I don't get paid for this. I have no obligation to continue this, but just perhaps, I felt it was worth waiting until I had the time to respond properly (I actually have a life outside boards, shocking I know) on a thread that warranted closer attention, instead of just posting as fast as possible to get it out there? Should I have commented on the thread at all before doing so, perhaps not, sue me.

As for the deletions, given the pissing contest a lot of these threads have been lately are you really so surprised someone decided to moderate the "Don't be a Jerk" rule a little harder? Usually the mods let you guys do pretty much whatever the hell you want. 

Not everything is about you, and you certainly aren't the only one that had comments deleted. If your comments were deleted for "talking bad to a volunteer" I can see at least 10~ comments in your recent history that would have been removed. Pretty sure it's just cause someone decided we had to actually enforce the rule for a bit.

1. It's your job, literally, to talk to people and handle their questions and issues with an unbiased opinion. At no point should you be like, "I don't want to deal with you because of _____!". You may not get paid, but I am sure that Riot laid out some kind of guidelines and/or rules for being in a position of power over everyone else. If you don't want to actually help people, no matter what issue it is, step down.

2. It is a job, it's a volunteer job. If you volunteer in person, you can't slack off and be like, "I don't get paid. Who cares?" The whole point is for you to be treating it like a job with no commitment or pay. You're meant to be doing it because you like to or because you need experience.

3. If you don't have the time to post a simple reply, don't bother posting on the thread. Period. Each post of yours should be thought out and clear. There's a reason why most Rioters don't mindlessly post on threads like people seem to expect. If they say the wrong thing, people jump to conclusions and misinformation is spread. Situations like this happen because of carelessness. Also, the whole, "I have a life outside of ___." argument is null and void and none of us cares. No one asked about your personal life. Don't throw it in our faces to hide your laziness.

4. Rules should either be enforced or not enforced at all. Don't half-ass rules. You can't have a rule be active for five minutes per day and then it's serious business. Get a grip. There should never be a point where a rule is ignored unless someone is offended and decides to use that rule to punish people hurting their feelings.

My God, the moderators on OCE are godawful. My cat could moderate better than you lot. Double standards, power abusive, and ignorant. The classic combo of teenagers in power.

1. You're not wrong, it is in essence a job, wrong wording there I suppose, but I am still also a player and can respond in the manner of just a player if I want to. I did agree that I probably shouldn't have posted in the thread before having a proper reply for the OP. I let my frustration get the best of me, which obviously isn't ideal.

2. When it's things that actually involve my position I hardly slack off. In fact I spend far more time on some posts than I really should just to make sure I have given all the info, and I do it because I enjoy it. What I don't enjoy is having someone comment on everything I do, with the express purpose of undermining me because they think I lie for fun or something. Why would I engage with that? It's not productive.

3. Pretty much, yes. I shouldn't have replied, but I do carefully consider all my posts. Frustrations colour some of those posts, but I don't just word vomit and post. I also never said anything false, so while the timing wasn't ideal, I wasn't being completely careless. The life outside was largely sarcasm. It should be obvious just from how much time I spend on boards that I do in fact give a shit, but I also have other priorities.

4. They are, but the mods have always been pretty lenient on what constitutes breaking the "Don't be a jerk" rule. It was at a standard where the rule was rarely blatantly broken and so rarely moderated. Recently though things have been very heated, hence the deletions. Posts were getting reported *on both 'sides'* and those were visibly used as the standard, because posts rarely get reported.

it is actually illegal in australia for corporations and private companies to involve volunteers from outside their organisation. (a riot employee can volunteer their time on the forums - that is legal.)

this is the root of all the current problems. they will do anything to save a few bucks and won't invest anything unless it will directly increase their bottom line.

the massive irony here is that some of these people being illegally unpaid are the ones denying this fact and defending this company to the death the most.
I mean, technically no, you can kinda get away with it as "work experience" though, with that part your supposed to also not be giving just busy work (IE. boards)

there are also rules for 'work experience'. namely:

    must be a vocational placement
    the person must not be doing “productive” work 
    the main benefit of the arrangement should be to the person doing the placement, and 
    it must be clear that the person is receiving a meaningful learning experience, training or skill development. 

is being a moderator a vocation? if it isn't then this is already unlawful. but obviously it is as there are people that get paid to be moderators.

these people are tasked with moderating the boards. they are not just observing an employee and learning. they are literally, for the most part, doing the actual work.

riot/tencent are clearly the main beneficiaries of this arrangement. 1. they are getting free labor and increasing their bottom line. 2. the moderation, ie the actual work done, directly benefits them.

hard to see how this is a _meaningful_ learning experience but i don't know, you would have to ask them. but this ties into the previous points. it appears that they are just doing free work rather than directly observing or being trained by someone from the company that they then will take with them into the work force.

i mean, it's pretty obvious that they are not people doing 'work experience' or an internship anyway. they do refer to themselves as volunteers.

it seems someone at riot conveniently doesn't realise that the laws here are a bit different to those in the united states, or they just don't give a shit. fair work ombudsman can't actually make them do anything and it wouldn't actually be worth the time and money for someone to take them to the supreme court over.
